name: badlock
author: hoover
description: My friend claims this is the authentication contract used in a proxy system he's been working on. Although I couldn't get access to the source code, I did manage to find the bytecode. Honestly, what I found was concerning. It's clear that we don't even need the source code to justify our concerns.

name: breaker
author: fantomet
description: Did you know that "breaking" a program can mean more than one thing? GDB certainly has its own idea of what that means. Unfortunately, a cat ran across my keyboard in the middle of debugging, and now everything looks like nonsense. Can you make sense of the chaos and recover the flag?

name: car-park
author: simen e
description:
I parked my car, but I have forgotten where. Can you help me find it?
The flag is the norwegian organisation number of the company whose car park this is. The flag matches NNS\{\d{9}\}

name: chail

description: If you like cloud-native architecture, then you'll LOVE this messaging app! Say hi to the cloud-native solution to real-time messaging for you and your friends! Being cloud-native and all, security and zero-trust comes first, right?

description: Can you solve the Collatz Conjecture?

name: ctf-speaker
author: simen e
description: I heard some strange sounds at the last CTF I attended, so I got out my analyser. You may need the analyser software from https://www.ellisys.com/better_analysis/bta_latest.htm

name: dotdotdot
author: simen e
description:
.NET is compiled into so-called Common Language, which is interpreted by a virtual machine. This means that code can work on multiple platforms.
Additionally it is easy to recover readable code, for instance using dotPeek or ILSpy.

name: dsp
author: simen e
description: This nRF52840 based flag checker accepts an analogue flag signal and performs digital signal processing on it. If the flag is detected, it lights up an LED.

name: enemies
author: Blorptopia & Platinumaniac
description:
Experience the next level of software for sharing memes and bad code with your colleauges!


As we noticed the IT department wasn't having so much fun, so we added a custom widget that anyone can send that flashes the flag on the screen of the admin, sort of like a jumpscare but for credentials.
Don't worry - only the admins can see it.

author: 0xle
description: The CTF is coming to an end, and we would like your feedback!

name: gollum
author: Vealending
description: Yess, you can looks at it… but not takes it away, preciousss. No, no, never removes it!

description: It's christmas day, but I think you would like to crash the party

description:
I love grooving, do you? Send me some of your best grooves!

Please solve the challenge locally before starting an instance!

name: guardrails

description: I wrote this little service to store my secrets safely. It's so secure I even store my flag in it!

name: haatetepe
author: fslaktern
description:
The best haatetepe server in Norway comes with speed, small size and modular routing. I've disabled the /flag route for now, though. Check out the server and let me know what you think! I haven't done any benchmarks, but I bet it's faster than NGINX, and it uses less than 1MB memory!

It's in its (very) early stages, but I'm planning on implementing the rest of the HTTP header specification when I get time. Thanks for stopping by!

name: holychem
author: hoover
description: A chemist seems to be passing secret notes during an exam... but their messages are encoded in a strange cipher I've never seen before! Can you analyze the traffic, decipher their scheme, and make sense of it? (I'd like the answer to his question too...)

name: huffameg
author: hoover
description: I don't understand, this just needs to return true! Hey Alexa, play "Tante Sofies sinte vise" until we've solved this challenge...

name: jwarmup
author: 0xle
description: My application was written in a modern- and memory safe language known as Java. It contains my secret, can you read it?

description: You might be fast, but are you faster than libc?

name: landing
author: simen e
description:
I just landed here, but where am I.
The flag is the name of the island I landed on. An example is NNS{Santorini}

name: lesc
author: simen e
description: I sniffed that someone was reading the flag, but I think it is encrypted. You may need the analyser software from https://www.ellisys.com/better_analysis/bta_latest.htm

I heard "link-in-bio" sites were the hot new thing, so I gave it a shot.
The report reviewer uses Chrome 136.
There is no need to bruteforce in this challenge.

I had to get the manuals for my GNU/Linux commands, so I made this.
Flag is at /get_flag

name: mandatory
author: hoover
description: Sometimes the most straightforward approach is the best approach. This simple flag checker hides its secret. Can you reverse engineer the binary to extract the flag?

name: mountaineer-turbo
author: fantomet
description:
I'm standing on top of this river next to a small town about 300m away, the mountain I'm looking at is 3060m tall and is approximately 3700m away, can you find out which town im next to? 
Flag: NNS{name_of_town}

name: mvm

description: I present the minimalistic instruction set

name: noters
author: fslaktern
description: A blazingly-fast, memory-safe, CRUD-compatible note-taking app written in nearly 1000 lines of safe Rust. No unsafe and no memory errors, yet still a pwn challenge. Everything looks safe. Everything compiles. Even clippy is happy. But something still feels off, and it's not Rust's fault.

description: oops, I left the codomain at home

name: origami
author: Zukane
description: Origami is a ntruly marvellous artform

name: parcellocker
author: fslaktern
description:
These new parcel lockers promise convenience: no queues, no staff, and 24/7 access. Everything is managed through a web UI, complete with API documentation at `/api/docs`. Your task as a user is simple: open the app, claim your parcel, and the assigned locker slot will unlock.

However, rumours are spreading - someone has already found a way to open any slot in any locker. Can you do it too?

name: point-encryption-1
author: Ordboka
description:
I found this hard problem online, and I thought since it was a hard problem, it must be a good starting point for a cryptosystem since they rely on hard problems.

The problem relies on the function are_equidistant_to_point_on_closest_line(x,y) which can be described as follows: Given two points, x and y, within the unit square, the function is true if there is a point on the edge of the square closest to point x, that is equidistant from both x and y. Since it is a hard problem, it's up to you to implement the function!

For this challenge I will choose a secret point X, and then allow you to encrypt any text. Can you use that to decrypt the flag?

name: point-encryption-2
author: Ordboka
description:
I found this hard problem online, and I thought since it was a hard problem, it must be a good starting point for a cryptosystem since I know that they rely on hard problems.

The problem relies on the function are_equidistant_to_point_on_closest_line(x,y) which can be described as follows: Given two points, x and y, within the unit square, the function is true if there is a point on the edge of the square closest to point x, that is equidistant from both x and y. Since it is a hard problem, it's up to you to implement the function!

For this challenge I will prove how secure the system is, by allowing you to generate as many different keys as you want, and use them to encrypt your own texts.

name: read-the-rules
author: 0xle
description: Have you read the rules? Join our Discord server if you haven't done so already: https://discord.gg/9AZr3WKrjG

description: I belive someone accidentally leaked some very sensitive data and deleted it straight away. Let's remind them of one of the blockchain's core principles, everything is immutable 🕵️

description: You may have seen a notes app before, but this one is 100% memory safe:)

name: tobe

description:
Tobe is a vault for storing the flag, only those with a valid key may get the flag.
To increase security the key is stored absolutely nowhere :)

name: touching-grass
author: SimenBai
description:
Everyone is always talking about touching some grass; so I finally did. But can you tell me where the house I saw is located?
The flag is the geohash (7 chars) of where the house is located. E.g. NNS{kpbpbpb}

name: translator-not-clanker
author: fslaktern
description: I AM A TRANSLATOR. GIVE ME A WORD AND I WILL TRANSLATE. GIVE ME A LIFE STORY AND I WILL TRANSLATE. GIVE ME NOTHING AND I WILL NOT UNDERSTAND WHAT YOU MEAN, NOT BECAUSE I AM DUMB, BUT BECAUSE I DO NOT WANT TO UNDERSTAND. CALL ME A CLANKER AND I WILL UPSET YOU IN WAYS THAT YOU CAN NOT COMPREHEND, YET.

name: viewing-pulses
author: simen e
description:
Logic analysis is a fundamental technique of hardware reverse engineering.
The attached recording is of a UART signal. It is taken in PulseView, a program that allows logic recording and protocol decoding.

name: wannaflag
author: hoover
description: Psst, don't tell the organizers, but do you want a flag? Just run this and get a free flag! Please try it out and see for yourself. Isn't it great to get free flags like that?

name: wannarealflag

description:
A real flag is better than a fake one. Unfortunately, the program that should print the flag seems buggy? I can't get it to output the correct flag.

Flag format: NNS{url}
